Algorithm that transforms ciphertext back to plaintext
The Caesar cipher is a weak encryption technique due to its simplicity and vulnerability to various cryptanalysis methods.
The Playfair cipher is relatively stronger than the remaining algorithms due to its polygraphic nature and key-dependent letter substitutions.
While not as secure as the one-time pad, the Hill cipher offers a higher level of security compared to the other algorithms on the list.
This algorithm provides perfect security when implemented correctly, making it the most secure encryption technique.
Although it offers limited security, the row transposition cipher is slightly more secure than the following algorithm.
The rail fence technique is the least secure among the listed algorithms, being susceptible to frequency analysis and other attacks due to its predictable pattern.
The monoalphabetic cipher\'s consistent letter substitution renders it weak, susceptible to attacks like frequency analysis due to its predictable pattern.
